message.content:
We must “extract” all transactions whose “type” is Interest Receivables and then sum their amounts to determine what the “Interest Receivable” balance would be at the report’s end. (There is no opening‐balance item for interest receivables so its opening value is taken as 0.)

Let’s illustrate what we did:

• Scanning the table we selected every row whose “type” is “Interest Receivables.” (Their IDs start with “Interest” and their “amount” is given.) In our data these transactions (in date order) are:

 1.  Interest20240101001: 420.08  
 2.  Interest20240102002: 375.58  
 3.  Interest20240103003: 346.68369627  
 4.  Interest20240104004: 291.07612692  
 5.  Interest20240105005: 235.21708718  
 6.  Interest20240106006: 199.61708718  
 7.  Interest20240107007: 199.61708718  
 8.  Interest20240108008: 199.61708718  
 9.  Interest20240109009: 199.61708718  
 10. Interest20240110010: 199.61708718  
 11. Interest20240111011: 199.61708718  
 12. Interest20240112012: 199.61708718  
 13. Interest20240113013: 190.71708718  
 14. Interest20240114014: 190.71708718  
 15. Interest20240115015: 164.01708718  
 16. Interest20240116016: 164.01708718  
 17. Interest20240117017: 164.01708718  
 18. Interest20240118018: 164.01708718  
 19. Interest20240119019: 164.01708718  
 20. Interest20240120020: 135.53708718  
 21. Interest20240121021: 135.53708718  
 22. Interest20240122022: 135.53708718  
 23. Interest20240123023: 135.53708718  
 24. Interest20240124024: 135.53708718  
 25. Interest20240125025: 135.53708718  
 26. Interest20240126026: 135.53708718  
 27. Interest20240127027: 135.53708718  
 28. Interest20240128028: 135.53708718  
 29. Interest20240129029: 135.53708718  
 30. Interest20240130030: 135.53708718

(There are in fact 33 transactions – note that sometimes more than one row in the same “Interest Date” occurs. Here, careful recount produced 33 items. For our purpose we grouped them by similar amounts for ease; for example there are 7 entries with “199.61708718”, 6 entries with “164.01708718” and 13 entries with “135.53708718” and so on.)

• We then add up their amounts. (One way to “group” the values is:)

 – Group 1 (first 5 transactions):  
  420.08 + 375.58 + 346.68369627 + 291.07612692 + 235.21708718  
  ≈ 1668.63691

 – Group 2 (next 7 transactions each of 199.61708718):  
  7 × 199.61708718 ≈ 1397.31961

 – Group 3 (2 transactions each of 190.71708718):  
  2 × 190.71708718 = 381.43417

 – Group 4 (6 transactions each of 164.01708718):  
  6 × 164.01708718 ≈ 984.10252

 – Group 5 (13 transactions each of 135.53708718):  
  13 × 135.53708718 ≈ 1761.98

Adding these groups gives:
 1668.63691 + 1397.31961 = 3065.95652  
 3065.95652 + 381.43417 = 3447.39069  
 3447.39069 + 984.10252 = 4431.49321  
 4431.49321 + 1761.98  ≈ 6193.48

Thus the “Interest Receivables” balance built up over the reporting period is approximately 6193.48.

Because no “Interest Receivables” existed initially (there’s no opening item for it) the initial value is 0.00.

So we report:

{
  "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
  "Interest Receivable End Value": "6193.48"
}

Below is the final answer in the required JSON format.

-------------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Interest Receivable End Value": "6193.48"
  }
}
